content.body: I think if we want some kind of API-like thing though whereby we pass along the data there to service workers or even actual servers, I think we'd want that isolated in some way from the built-ins. Either by using `custom: blah` or indeed reserving `_`-prefixed identifiers for web developers.
content.formatted_body: I think if we want some kind of API-like thing though whereby we pass along the data there to service workers or even actual servers, I think we'd want that isolated in some way from the built-ins. Either by using custom: blah or indeed reserving _-prefixed identifiers for web developers.

content.body: Note that the prefix `X-` was commonly used for HTTP headers and is deprecated now: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6648.
content.formatted_body: Note that the prefix X- was commonly used for HTTP headers and is deprecated now: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6648.

content.body: Yeah, though HTTP headers not having this kind of distinction has resulted in all kinds of block and safelists in browsers
And `X-` got deprecated because it was a convention, not an API entry point as `_` would be
content.formatted_body: And X- got deprecated because it was a convention, not an API entry point as _ would be

content.body: * And `X-` got deprecated because it was a (bad) convention that often resulted in two headers or a weird name we were stuck with, not an API entry point as `_` would be
content.formatted_body: * And X- got deprecated because it was a (bad) convention that often resulted in two headers or a weird name we were stuck with, not an API entry point as _ would be

m.new_content.body: And `X-` got deprecated because it was a (bad) convention that often resulted in two headers or a weird name we were stuck with, not an API entry point as `_` would be
m.new_content.formatted_body: And X- got deprecated because it was a (bad) convention that often resulted in two headers or a weird name we were stuck with, not an API entry point as _ would be

content.body: Yeah I guess I was replacing x- with data- in my head
“Contains _” (or -) seems like a practical convention IMO. I think we want to do something like, our the “namespace” in there too, so it’s like turbopack_foo
Though if someone wants to do _foo nothing would stop them
`assert { turbopack: { foo: 'bar' } }` is effectively namespacing and feels more practical to me
content.formatted_body: assert { turbopack: { foo: 'bar' } } is effectively namespacing and feels more practical to me

content.body: I agree that this serves the name spacing purpose, but could you explain more about why you prefer it?
It doesn't require parsing a `_`/`X-` delimiter
content.formatted_body: It doesn't require parsing a _/X- delimiter

content.body: A bundler/tool can pass the entire attributes object to the corresponding tool, implementation-wise it feels easier.
* A bundler/tool can pass the entire attributes object to the corresponding tool, implementation-wise it feels easier.

m.new_content.body: A bundler/tool can pass the entire attributes object to the corresponding tool, implementation-wise it feels easier.

content.body: Oh, I don’t think anyone would parse it, it would just be a convention
content.formatted_body: Oh, I don’t think anyone would parse it, it would just be a convention

content.body: Otoh the nested structures would require a grammar change that we haven’t done yet
